descriptivenote.p: DACS was used as the primary description standard.

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: Finding aid encoded by Manuscript Division staff.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Electrical engineer and educator. Correspondence, book drafts, articles, reports, printed matter, and notes in both physical and digital formats relating to Casazza's career in the electric power industry. Materials in physical formats also include photographs and clippings.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The papers of John A. Casazza were given to the Library of Congress by Casazza's daughter, Joan Fram, in 2020.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of John A. Casazza were arranged and described by Emily Flint with the assistance of Karen Linn Femia, Chad Conrady, and Kathleen O'Neill in 2021 and 2022.

Digital files were received as part of the John A. Casazza Papers on a variety of storage media, each of which was assigned a unique digital ID number. Use the digital ID number to request access copies of the files associated with each media. Two 3.5-inch floppy disks contained corrupted files, which were extracted using a hex editor and saved as text files. Some Microsoft Word files on 3.5-inch floppies were corrupted and converted to text files for access. A description of the standard processes taken on all born digital records can be found in the Processing History Note: Born Digital Collections Material at https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mss/eadmss.digital.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Videocassettes and sound cassettes have been transferred to the Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division where they are identified as part of the John A. Casazza Papers. Patrons are encouraged to contact the Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division in advance of a research visit.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Materials from the John A. Casazza Papers are governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.) and other applicable international copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of John A. Casazza are open to research. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use. Access to digital content is available onsite only in the Manuscript Reading Room and requires advanced notice. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting.

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Digital files were created in a Windows operation system, version unknown. Digital files in the collection include text documents in Microsoft Word 97-2003 (.doc), plain text files (.txt), and Adobe Acrobat PDF 1.4 (.pdf), presentations in Microsoft PowerPoint v.4 (.ppt), and images in Graphics Interface format v. .87a and .89a (.gif) and JPEG File Interchange format (.jpg). Digital files can be accessed with modern software or standard file viewer.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container or digital ID number, John A. Casazza Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Born, Brooklyn, N.Y.
Student, Cooper Union School of Engineering, New York, N.Y.
Ensign, United States Navy
B.E.E., Cornell University, Ithaca, N.Y.
Engineer; general manager, Planning and Research; and vice president, Planning and Research, Public Service Electric and Gas Co., Newark, N.J.
Married Madeline Russo (died 2014)
Vice president, Stone and Webster Management Consultants, New York, N.Y.
President, chairman of the board, and board member, Casazza, Schultz & Associates, Washington, D.C.; moved in 1984 to Arlington, Va.
Received Herman Halperin Electric Transmission and Distribution Award from the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE)
Member, Energy Engineering Board of the National Research Council, Washington, D.C.
Published The Development of Electric Power Transmission: The Role Played by Technology, Institutions, and People. New York: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
Received Philip Sporn Award from the International Council on Large Electric Systems (CIGRE)
Founder and president, American Education Institute, Arlington, Va.; moved in 1998 to Springfield, Va.
Board member, Board of Adjustment, Commonwealth Edison, Chicago, Ill.
Outside director, Georgia Systems Operations Corporation, Tucker, Ga.
Member, Executive Committee of New York State Reliability Council
Edited with George C. Loehr The Evolution of Electric Power Transmission Under Deregulation: Selected Readings. Piscataway, N.J.: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
Published Sham? Shame!: Inside the Electric Power Industry. Springfield, Va.: American Education Institute

chronitemset.event: Co-founder, Power Engineers Supporting Truth, Springfield, Va.
Published with Frank Delea Understanding Electric Power Systems: An Overview of the Technology and the Marketplace , 1st ed. Piscataway, N.J.: IEEE Press; Hoboken, N.J.: Wiley

chronitem.event: Published Forgotten Roots: Electric Power, Profits, Democracy and a Profession. Springfield, Va.: self-published
Published with Frank Delea Understanding Electric Power Systems: An Overview of the Technology, the Marketplace and Government Regulation , 2nd ed. Piscataway, N.J.: IEEE Press; Hoboken, N.J.: Wiley
Published Superpower: A Historical Novel About the People Responsible for our National Power Grid. Mustang, Okla.: Tate Publishing & Enterprises, LLC
Died, Fairfax, Va.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of John A. Casazza (1924-2019) span the years 1938-2018, with the bulk of the material dating from 1970 to 2012. The collection documents Casazza’s career in the electric power industry as an engineer, educator, and author. The papers are in English. The collection is organized into five series: Speeches and Writings File, Subject File, Course Materials, Miscellany, and Digital File.

The collection documents Casazza’s long career as an electrical engineer and business executive at Public Service Electric and Gas Company. His papers also include material related to his consulting firm, Casazza, Schultz & Associates, his teaching efforts with the American Education Institute, his advocacy work with Power Engineers Supporting Truth, and the writing of his books and other publications. Much of Casazza's work was published under the name Jack Casazza. As Casazza believed engineers and their employers have a moral responsibility to provide a service to society instead of prioritizing commercial interests, the papers frequently explore ethical issues within the electric power industry. While he advocated for engineers to have a greater role in setting electric power policy, Casazza also worked to improve the technical competence of existing government officials through educational programs.
The collection’s series are listed and briefly described below. A fuller description of each series and a list of its contents can be accessed in the series descriptions within the container list.
The Speeches and Writings File series includes book drafts, articles, reports, unpublished memoirs, and talks written by Casazza.
The Subject File series contains files on a variety of topics and issues related to the electric power industry.
The Course Materials series documents educational programs offered by Casazza, Schultz & Associates and the American Education Institute.
The Miscellany series includes correspondence, photographs, and other miscellaneous material pertaining to Casazza’s life and career.
The Digital File series contains the contents of floppy disks and CDs created and used by Casazza and overlaps with material from the other series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into five series:

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

subject.part: Electric power systems--Design and construction--United States.

scopecontent.p: The Speeches and Writings File series includes book drafts, articles, reports, unpublished memoirs, and talks written by Casazza. The series contains drafts of several books by Casazza, including the first edition of Understanding Electric Power Systems . Research materials, correspondence, reviews, and copies of figures and illustrations are also present for some of his books. The chronological file in this series contains copies of Casazza’s professional articles, conference talks, reports, lectures, and expert testimonies given before the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and various congressional committees. Casazza collected these materials in a set of twelve binders, assigned each binder a number (i.e. “Book I”), and created separate indexes for the contents of each binder. The container list maintains his original organization of these materials. A complete index of all twelve “Books” is included at the end of the chronological file. Additional articles and reports not part of the chronological file are listed individually in the container list. Some articles explore Casazza’s personal views on topics like race relations and religion. The series also contains copies of Casazza’s unpublished memoirs and a collection of writings he identified as his most important works. This series also includes a selection of writings by others that feature Casazza's annotations. For the most heavily annotated books, the entire book was retained. In other cases, only the relevant pages were photocopied. Also present is a draft of former Federal Power Commission chairman Joseph C. Swidler’s autobiography. After Swidler's death, an edited version of this autobiography was published as Power and the Public Interest: The Memoirs of Joseph C. Swidler .
Material types include book drafts, articles, reports, correspondence, notes, and printed matter.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of writing or material.

scopecontent.p: The Subject File series contains files on a variety of topics and issues related to the electric power industry. Topics include transmission capacity, federal energy legislation, major electric power failures, and the environmental impact of utility companies. The files on national power surveys document the Federal Power Commission's 1964 survey and Casazza’s advocacy for an updated survey during the early 2000s. Also of interest are the files on the Northeast blackout of 2003. Casazza formed Power Engineers Supporting Truth (PEST) with Frank Delea, George C. Loehr, and Raymond Maliszewski in response to this event. PEST criticized the federal government’s investigation of the blackout, expressed concern about the impact of government deregulation on the North American electric power system, and looked to prevent future power failures from occurring. A small portion of the Subject File documents Casazza’s interest in connections between science and religion.
Material types include reports, articles, correspondence, printed matter, notes, and clippings.

did.unittitle: Union for the Coordination of Transmission of Electricity, 2007
Electric utility industry structure and regulation, 1952, 1959-1975
Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Energy Policy Committee, 2008-2013
Reliability methods, import and export requirements, 1970
Transmission and planning methodology in the U.S., 1975

scopecontent.p: The Course Materials series documents educational programs offered by Casazza, Schultz & Associates and the American Education Institute. Some programs were aimed at experienced engineers as continuing education opportunities. Others were intended for non-engineers involved in setting electric power policy, such as officials from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Department of Defense. Course topics include transmission system planning and design, pricing of transmission services, causes and effects of electric power failures, electric system security, and the history of the electric power industry.
Material types include lecture notes, course schedules, correspondence, course evaluations, and transparencies.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by course title or type of material.

scopecontent.p: The Miscellany series includes correspondence, photographs, and other miscellaneous material pertaining to Casazza’s life and career. Much of the correspondence is related to Casazza’s interest in improving the technical competence of government officials and his concerns about the future of the engineering profession. Congratulatory letters on various professional accomplishments and a small amount of personal correspondence are also included. The photographs and clippings primarily document Casazza’s projects in the electric power industry. Also present are several portraits of Casazza.

Material types include correspondence, photographs, clippings, notes, a family history of the Casazza and Russo families, an oral history interview, copies of a patent, and résumés and other biographical material.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic or type of material.

did.unittitle: Oral history interview with IEEE History Center, 1994
Patent for power injector control means for transmission networks, 1974-1976
Press clippings and publicity photographs, binder, 1949-1951, 1964-2004

scopecontent.p: The Digital File series contains the contents of floppy disks and CDs created and used by Casazza and overlaps with material from the other series. The series documents his professional activities with Power Engineers Supporting Truth, the American Education Insitute, and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Also included are copies of various book drafts, speeches and slide presentations, articles, and reports written by Casazza. Major topics include electric power failures (especially the Northeast blackout of 2003), electric power deregulation, and labor and personnel issues affecting the electrical engineering profession.
Material types include correspondence, meeting minutes, PowerPoint presentations, book drafts, articles, and reports.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by subject or type of material. The file structure of the digital content has been maintained as received.
